Class Scale<D extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable>

java.lang.Object
org.interworldtransport.cladosG.Scale<D>
Type Parameters:
D - CladosF number like RealF, RealD, ComplexF, ComplexD. They must be children of ProtoN AND implement Field.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Modal, Unitized
public final class Scale<D extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> extends Object implements Unitized, Modal
This class contains cladosF numbers that act together as the coefficients of a monad. They are all children of ProtoN and implement Field, so they have both a sense of 'units' and support basic arithmetic operations. Which numbers are contained internally, therefore, is tracked by two private elements. One contains a reference to a Cardinal that all the numbers should share. The other is a reference two one of the CladosField elements so we know whether this Scale is expected to contain real or complex numbers and at what level of floating point precision. Access to the two private elements is managed by their 'get' methods. getCardinal() and getMode(). There are set methods for them too, but they are package protected methods that should not be handled much by developers of physical models.

The data structure used to represent 'coefficients' used to be a fixed array that had the same length as the number of blades in a monad's basis. That has been modernized to an IdentityHashMap contained within this class. The basis against which the map is applicable can be referenced by another private element, but shouldn't be manipulated once set. The private element is finalized.

An IdentityHashMap was used instead of a simpler HashMap in order to get reference equality between map keys instead of object equality. Map Keys are Blades from the basis, so reference equality is the correct expectation when comparing keys. Typical use of keys from the map occurs with streams that effectively iterate through the blades for access to coefficients in the encompassing vector space. The information within a blade is far less important than which blade it is, thus reference equality is what is needed.

Map Values are CladosF numbers like RealF or ComplexD. Because they are objects instead of primitives, they behave much like Java's boxed primitives. In fact, they would BE those boxed primitives if not for the need to track units in physical models. For example, one meter is not one second. No equality test should pass.

Because values are objects, care must be taken once one has a reference to them. Any reference to one enables a developer to change it without the Scale or Monad knowing. This is the hydra monster named Mutability. It IS a danger here. Many of Scale's methods copy inbound numbers to avoid altering them, but some do not INTENTIONALLY.

1. Coefficient settors that accept arrays do NOT copy values before placing them in the internal map. BEWARE BEWARE BEWARE

2. Put() does not copy the incoming value before placing it in the internal map. Again... BEWARE.

3. Coefficient settors that accept maps DO COPY values before placing them in the internal map. Any object from which values are taken to be used here are safe from the hydra.

4. All gettors for coefficients provide direct references to values in the map. The most common use is INTENTIONAL MUTABILITY, so... BEWARE THE HYDRA. The safest way to use them is within streams / lambdas.

GENERAL NOTE | Many of the methods for Scale look a lot like Monad, so one can reasonably wonder why all the extra stuff in Monad when Scale looks enough like a tuple to represent things. The primary difference is that Scale contains only the coefficients and references a basis like what we got used to as students. That's not enough because a basis is only enough to represent linear combinations for a vector space. Other geometric meanings aren't in the basis. They are in the product table. Combining product table and basis into an 'algebra' gives a MUCH better description of a 'tuple's' reference frame than a vector space.

Version:
2.0
Author:
Dr Alfred W Differ

    • Scale

      public Scale(CladosField pMode, Basis pB, Cardinal pCard)
      This is the constructor to use when one does not have the actual map ready, but will provide it later.
      Parameters:
      pMode - CladosField enumeration so we know what kind of ProtoN to expect from get()
      pB - Basis to which the blades used in the internal map belong.
      pCard - Incoming Cardinal to reference here.

    • Scale

      public Scale(CladosField pMode, Basis pB, Map<Blade,D> pInMap)
      This is the constructor to use when one already has a map built and a reference to the basis on which the map relies for keys.
      This is NOT a copy constructor. Use it when you fully intend for the offered map to directly provide the weights in this Scale.
      Parameters:
      pMode - CladosField enumeration so we know what kind of ProtoN to expect from get()
      pB - Basis to which the blades offered in the map belong.
      pInMap - This is a Map to copy. Probably a view of another Scale object.

    • Scale

      public Scale(Scale<D> pIn)
      Straight forward copy constructor. Copies values ONLY. Re-uses keys.
      Parameters:
      pIn - Scale to be imitated.

  • Method Details

    • conjugate

      public Scale<D> conjugate()
      This method conjugates all the values in the internal map, but leaves the blades of the algebra untouched.
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • get

      public D get(Blade pB)
      This method imitates the 'get()' method in a map. Offer a key and receive a value in return. In this particular case, keys are blades from the basis and values are weights of those blades.
      Parameters:
      pB - Blade to use as key in internal map
      Returns:
      A ProtoN child related to this blade

    • getBasis

      public Basis getBasis()
      Simple gettor method for the Basis associated with this object. Be aware this basis is finalized, so it won't be changeable to a new basis. What might be possible is altering the internal details of the basis, so be careful.
      Returns:
      Basis in use in this.

    • getCardinal

      public Cardinal getCardinal()
      Simple gettor method for the Cardinal associated with this object.
      Specified by:
      getCardinal in interface Unitized
      Returns:
      Cardinal in use in this.

    • getWeights

      public D[] getWeights()
      This method imitates one from V1.0 and should be rarely used. For old code needing to handle coefficients directly, this is how to get at them. The smarter approach, though, is to call the parent class method values() and receive a Collection of coefficients instead of an array. Do it that way and they are already of a known ProtoN child class.
      Since the internal map can accept any of the CladosF numbers as values, there is a cast to a 'generic' type within this method. This would normally cause warnings by the compiler since the generic named in the internal map IS a ProtoN child AND casting an unchecked type could fail at runtime.
      That won't happen here when CladosF builders are used. They can't build anything that is NOT a ProtoN child. They can't even build a ProtoN instance directly. Therefore, only children can arrive as the value parameter of the 'put' function. Thus, there is no danger of a failed cast operation... until someone creates a new ProtoN child class and fails to update all builders.
      Returns:
      an array of ProtoN children.

    • getMode

      public CladosField getMode()
      Simple gettor method reporting the Scale's internal mode.
      Specified by:
      getMode in interface Modal
      Returns:
      CladosField element reporting which ProtoN child is expected in the list of this Scale.

    • getPScalar

      public D getPScalar()
      This method imitates the 'get()' method in a map, but specializes in the pscalar blade key.
      Since the internal map can accept any of the CladosF numbers as values, there is a cast to a 'generic' type within this method. This would normally cause warnings by the compiler since the generic named in the internal map IS a ProtoN child AND casting an unchecked type could fail at runtime.
      That won't happen here when CladosF builders are used. They can't build anything that is NOT a ProtoN child. They can't even build a ProtoN instance directly. Therefore, only children can arrive as the value parameter of the 'put' function. Thus, there is no danger of a failed cast operation... until someone creates a new ProtoN child class and fails to update all builders.
      Returns:
      A ProtoN child related to the pscalar blade

    • getScalar

      public D getScalar()
      This method imitates the 'get()' method in a map, but specializes in the scalar blade key.
      Since the internal map can accept any of the CladosF numbers as values, there is a cast to a 'generic' type within this method. This would normally cause warnings by the compiler since the generic named in the internal map IS a ProtoN child AND casting an unchecked type could fail at runtime.
      That won't happen here when CladosF builders are used. They can't build anything that is NOT a ProtoN child. They can't even build a ProtoN instance directly. Therefore, only children can arrive as the value parameter of the 'put' function. Thus, there is no danger of a failed cast operation... until someone creates a new ProtoN child class and fails to update all builders.
      Returns:
      A ProtoN child related to the scalar blade

    • mainInvolution

      public Scale<D> mainInvolution()
      This method imitates the main involution. All generators in each blade flip sign, so the implications for the values in the internal map are worked out. No typeMismatch can occur.
      This is what we called a parity inversion where generator.# goes to -1.0 * generator.#, but that's not a good name for it going forward.
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • isNotZeroAt

      public boolean isNotZeroAt(Blade pB)
      This is a short hand method to reduce checking in other classes to simply asking the question regarding the value rather than handle all the various ProtoN children separately.
      NOTE this tends to get used in filters in streams to minimize the number of coefficients processed in arithmetic operations. Non-zero ones contribute non-zero results to products, so this especially matters in O(N^2) calculations.
      Parameters:
      pB - Blade to use as key to discover if related value is non-zero.
      Returns:
      boolean False if the related value evaluates as ZERO in whatever number style it is.

    • isPScalarZero

      public boolean isPScalarZero()
      This is a short hand method to reduce checking in other classes to simply asking this one rather than handle all the various ProtoN children separately.
      Returns:
      boolean True if the pscalar value evaluates as ZERO in whatever number style it is.

    • isScalarZero

      public boolean isScalarZero()
      This is a short hand method to reduce checking in other classes to simply asking this one rather than handle all the various ProtoN children separately.
      Returns:
      boolean True if the scalar value evaluates as ZERO in whatever number style it is.

    • modulusSQSum

      public D modulusSQSum()
      This method takes all values in the map and returns one ProtoN child that has a real value that is equal to the square root of the sum of the SQModulus of each value.
      NOTE about suppressed type cast warnings | This method switches through the possible classes known as descendents of ProtoN. If the object to be copied is one of them, the method uses a constructor appropriate to it, but then casts the result back to the generic T before returning it.
      There is no danger to this with respect to the implementation of this method. The danger comes from mis-use of the method. If one passes a different kind of object that passes as a descendent of ProtoN implementing Field and Normalizable, this method might not detect it and return null. The type casting operation itself cannot fail, but unrecognized child classes do NOT get copied.
      This can happen if one extends ProtoN creating a new CladosF number. This method will not be aware of the new class until its implementation is updated.
      Because these are real numbers, though, we get away with simply summing the moduli instead. It does not perform a cardinal safety check and will throw the exception if that test fails.
      Returns:
      D ProtoN child that implements all the number interfaces too.

    • modulusSum

      public D modulusSum()
      This method takes all values in the map and returns one ProtoN child that has a real value that is equal to the square root of the sum of the SQModulus of each value.
      Because these are real numbers, though, we get away with simply summing the moduli instead. It does not perform a cardinal safety check and will throw the exception if that test fails.
      NOTE about suppressed type cast warnings | This method switches through the possible classes known as descendents of ProtoN. If the object to be copied is one of them, the method uses a constructor appropriate to it, but then casts the result back to the generic T before returning it.
      There is no danger to this with respect to the implementation of this method. The danger comes from mis-use of the method. If one passes a different kind of object that passes as a descendent of ProtoN implementing Field and Normalizable, this method might not detect it and return null. The type casting operation itself cannot fail, but unrecognized child classes do NOT get copied.
      This can happen if one extends ProtoN creating a new CladosF number. This method will not be aware of the new class until its implementation is updated.
      Returns:
      D ProtoN child that implements all the number interfaces too.

    • normalize

      public void normalize() throws FieldException
      This method normalizes the coefficients as if they were a vector in 2^N vector space described by the implied basis from the monad. It's pretty simple, though. Just add up the squares of the numbers and then take the square root to determine the magnitude and then invert that to scale the original numbers.
      Since the internal map can accept any of the CladosF numbers as values, there is a cast to a 'generic' type within this method. This would normally cause warnings by the compiler since the generic named in the internal map IS a ProtoN child AND casting an unchecked type could fail at runtime.
      That won't happen here when CladosF builders are used. They can't build anything that is NOT a ProtoN child. They can't even build a ProtoN instance directly. Therefore, only children can arrive as the value parameter of the 'put' function. Thus, there is no danger of a failed cast operation... until someone creates a new ProtoN child class and fails to update all builders.
      Throws:
      FieldException - This happens when normalizing something that has a zero magnitude. The exception is thrown by the invert() method and passed along here.

    • put

      public Scale<D> put(Blade pB, D pD)
      Put a key/value pair into the internal map of coefficients. A Blade acts as key. A ProtoN child acts as coefficient.
      Parameters:
      pB - Blade acting as key in the internal map
      pD - ProtoN child acting as the coefficient.
      Returns:
      Scale of Unit Abstract objects. Just this object after modification if it occurs.

    • reverse

      public Scale<D> reverse()
      This method reverses all the order of implied multiplication in blade generators and works out the sign implications for the values in the internal map. No typeMismatch can occur here.
      This method shows that blade reversion is handled HERE and not with the sign of the blades themselves. The sign in Blade is ONLY for the order of the enumset of its generators. Grade convolutions are remembered in Scale by flipping signs of the ProtoN child values in map.
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • scale

      public <T extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> Scale<D> scale(T pIn)
      This method scales all values in the internal map by the value offered provided there is no typeMatch failure. When there IS a type mismatch the number simply does not get scaled.
      The first stream filters for weights that pass the match test. The second stream scales them. That means the embedded IllegalARgumentException will never be thrown.
      Type Parameters:
      T - ProtoN child generic type support. Must also implement Field.
      Parameters:
      pIn - ProtoN child to use as a scaling element. Mode and cardinal MUST match values in map.
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • toXMLString

      public static final <T extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> String toXMLString(Scale<T> pS, String indent)
      This is an exporter of internal details to XML. It exists to bypass certain security concerns related to Java serialization of objects.
      Type Parameters:
      T - Some kind of number extending ProtoN that provides weights in the Scale.
      Parameters:
      pS - The Scale oject to be output as XML
      indent - String of 'tab' characters to get spacing right for human readable XML output.
      Returns:
      String formatted as XML containing information about the Algebra

    • getMap

      protected <T extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> Map<Blade,T> getMap()
      This is a simple gettor method, but it is most likly to be used to establish a stream of blades, values, or both from the internal map of this object. The map's keys are all blades from the object's basis. The map won't contain just a few blades as keys, though. It will contain every blade as a key paired to some unique CladosF number.
      Since the internal map can accept any of the CladosF numbers (and ProtoN itself though that would be useless) there is a cast to a 'generic' type before insertion into the map. This would normally cause warnings by the compiler since the generic named in the internal map IS a ProtoN child AND casting an unchecked type could fail at runtime.
      That won't happen here when CladosF builders are used. They can't build anything that is NOT a ProtoN child. They can't even build a ProtoN instance directly. Therefore, only children can arrive as the value parameter of the 'put' function. Thus, there is no danger of a failed cast operation... until someone creates a new ProtoN child class and fails to update all builders.
      Type Parameters:
      T - ProtoN child generic type support. Must also implement Field AND Normalizable.
      Returns:
      deliver the internal coefficients as the internal map.

    • setCardinal

      protected Scale<D> setCardinal(Cardinal pCard)
      The settor method supporting Unitized interface that isn't actually in the interface. If the cardinal to be set is different from the one already present, the weights are cleared out and set to zero. If the cardinal is the same one, nothing is done and this Scale is returned.
      Once a Cardinal is set, it basically can't be removed. It can be changed, but not eliminated entirely.
      Parameters:
      pCard - CladosField element to set as the mode.
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • setPScalarWeight

      protected <T extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> Scale<D> setPScalarWeight(D pIn)
      This method just sets the pscalar weight with a number that should satisfy type matches. If it does not get past the type match check, nothing is done to change any weights.
      Type Parameters:
      T - is a child of ProtoN used as the generic identity of the weights in this object.
      Parameters:
      pIn - D is a child of ProtoN to use as the pscalar weight.
      Returns:
      Scale of numbers for use in streaming operations if desired.

    • setScalarWeight

      protected <T extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> Scale<D> setScalarWeight(D pIn)
      This method just sets the scalar weight with a number that should satisfy type matches. If it does not get past the type match check, nothing is done to change any weights.
      Type Parameters:
      T - is a child of ProtoN used as the generic identity of the weights in this object.
      Parameters:
      pIn - D is a child of ProtoN to use as the pscalar weight.
      Returns:
      Scale of numbers for use in streaming operations if desired.

    • setWeightsArray

      protected <T extends ProtoN & Field & Normalizable> Scale<D> setWeightsArray(T[] pIn)
      This coefficient settor accepts an array of ProtoN numbers, assumes they are in basis index order, and then inserts them into the internal map by blade at that index.
      NOTE | Do NOT use this method if you intend the offered coefficient array to be disconnected from this object. It won't be. If you really must use this method that way, copy your coefficients first.
      Type Parameters:
      T - is a child of ProtoN used as the generic identity of the weights in this object.
      Parameters:
      pIn - Array of ProtoN children
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - This happens if the offered array does not have the same size as the basis. Good enough to ensure all blades are covered.

    • setWeightsMap

      protected Scale<D> setWeightsMap(Map<Blade,D> pInMap)
      This method sets the coefficients represented by this Scale. It accepts a map relating blades in the basis to CladosF.DivField children. It checks to see if the map is of the wrong size and throws an IllegalArgumentException if so.
      NOTE this method DEEP COPIES the inbound map to disconnect the map's source DivFields from the ones added to this object. This is the safest settor method to use when handing in information from other clados sources.
      Parameters:
      pInMap - Inbound Map relating blades to ProtoN child numbers.
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - This happens if the offered map does not have the same size as the basis. Good enough to ensure all blades are covered because Map doesn't allow duplicate keys.

    • setWeightsAtGrade

      protected Scale<D> setWeightsAtGrade(byte pGrade, D[] pIn)
      This coefficient settor accepts an array of ProtoN children, assumes they are in basis index order, and then inserts them into the internal map by blade at that index offset in the amount necessary to cover ONLY the grade suggested by the byte parameter.
      NOTE | Do NOT use this method if you intend the offered coefficient array to be disconnected from this object. It won't be. If you really must use this method that way, copy your coefficients first.
      Parameters:
      pGrade - byte integer naming the grade to be overwritten
      pIn - Array of ProtoN Children
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • weightsStream

      protected Stream<D> weightsStream()
      This is the compliment of a blade stream involving the scaling factors 'multiplied' by blades in the sense of a division field over a vector space. When forming a linear combination of blades to make a 'vector', these are the 'numbers' that scale each direction.
      Since the internal map can accept any of the CladosF numbers as values, there is a cast to a 'generic' type within this method. This would normally cause warnings by the compiler since the generic named in the internal map IS a ProtoN child AND casting an unchecked type could fail at runtime.
      That won't happen here when CladosF builders are used. They can't build anything that is NOT a ProtoN child. They can't even build a ProtoN instance directly. Therefore, only children can arrive as the value parameter of the 'put' function. Thus, there is no danger of a failed cast operation... until someone creates a new ProtoN child class and fails to update all builders.
      Returns:
      Stream of ProtoN children that are the coefficients represented as values in the internal map.

    • weightsParallelStream

      protected Stream<D> weightsParallelStream()
      This method returns a parallelizable stream of the weights in this scale. It is intended for wholesale operations on the weights that may be done in any order. It is mostly for use by the owning object of this Scale.
      Returns:
      A stream of weights as children of ProtoN.

    • zeroAll

      protected Scale<D> zeroAll()
      This method causes all coefficients to be set to zero using the offered cardinal.
      Returns:
      This Scale instance after coefficients are zero'd out.

    • zeroAllButGrade

      protected Scale<D> zeroAllButGrade(byte pGrade)
      This is a specialty method making use of setCoefficientsAtGrade for a specific purpose of grade suppression.
      Parameters:
      pGrade - byte integer naming the grade to be preserved
      Returns:
      This Scale instance after coefficients are zero'd out.

    • zeroAt

      public Scale<D> zeroAt(Blade pB)
      Zero the value at the offered blade.
      NOTE this doesn't remove the blade from the map because the basis should never change. The mapped value at that blade is zero'd.
      Parameters:
      pB - Blade key to zero out the related coefficient
      Returns:
      Scale object. Just this object after modification.

    • zeroAtGrade

      protected Scale<D> zeroAtGrade(byte pGrade)
      This is a specialty method making use of setCoefficientsAtGrade for a specific purpose of grade suppression.
      Parameters:
      pGrade - byte integer naming the grade to be overwritten
      Returns:
      This Scale instance after coefficients are zero'd out.
